title: Third victim reportedly dies after Pawtucket ice rink shooting
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Gerald Dorgan, 75, died after being critically injured in the February 16 Pawtucket ice rink shooting.
Rhonda Dorgan and Aidan Dorgan also died in the targeted family shooting at Dennis M. Lynch Arena.
Shooter Robert Dorgan shot himself after being disarmed at the arena; three civilians intervened.

title: Cat saved after days stuck in a tree following the blizzard that blanketed Rhode Island
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Matt Lyons climbed 40 to 50 feet to rescue a cat named Pixie stuck in a tree in Rhode Island.
Pixie was stranded in the tree for nearly two days during a historic snowstorm with three feet of snow.
Efforts by neighbors and emergency services failed, leading Lyons to climb the tree after seeing a Nextdoor post.

title: 4 questions facing Bruins as they return from Olympic break
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins face 25 games in eight weeks, starting Thursday against Columbus at TD Garden.
Bruins excelled before the Olympic break, but penalty kill issues and discipline remain a concern.
Potential trades or promoting prospect James Hagens could impact Boston's playoff push.

title: Fire erupts at MCI-Norfolk prison, no major injuries reported
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Fire erupted at MCI-Norfolk prison, quickly extinguished, with no major injuries reported.
Three incarcerated individuals treated for smoke inhalation; one staff member went to hospital as a precaution.
Officials are assessing damage and causes; fire's origin remains under investigation.

title: Stephen A. Smith endorses Jaylen Brown as an MVP candidate
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Stephen A. Smith endorses Jaylen Brown as a strong NBA MVP candidate for the 2025-26 season.
Despite key player losses, the Celtics are second in the East with a 38-19 record, largely due to Brown's performance.
Brown averages 29.2 points, 7 rebounds, and 4.9 assists, leading Boston in Jayson Tatum's absence.

title: Harvard professor on leave as college investigates ties to Jeffrey Epstein
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Harvard professor Martin Nowak is on paid leave amid an investigation into his ties with Jeffrey Epstein.
Epstein donated $6.5 million to establish Nowak's Program for Evolutionary Dynamics at Harvard in 2003.
Nowak visited Epstein's private island in 2013 and had over 4,000 connections with him in DOJ documents.

title: Malden educator, basketball coach charged with rape in incident involving high school student, officials say
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Scott Marino, Malden educator and basketball coach, charged with rape involving a high school student, has been placed on leave.
Charges against Marino include two counts of rape, indecent assault and battery, and selling liquor to a minor, officials say.
The Middlesex District Attorney’s Office is overseeing the case; the school district declined further comment due to privacy laws.

title: Red Sox’ Wilyer Abreu explains viral broken-bat check swing
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Wilyer Abreu's bat unexpectedly broke during a check swing in a game against the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Abreu felt something odd during a previous at-bat but didn't switch bats before the breakage.
Despite past injuries, Abreu hit 22 home runs in 2025 and won a second Golden Glove award.

title: All Mass. customers should have power fully restored by end of Friday night, Eversource says
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Eversource aims to restore power to 160,000 customers in Eastern Massachusetts by midnight Friday after a blizzard.
Major outages remain in Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard, Plymouth, and New Bedford as of Wednesday, affecting 121,000 Eversource customers.
National Grid has 3,000 customers without power, mainly on Nantucket, expecting restoration by Wednesday night.

title: Team USA captain Hilary Knight reacts to Trump’s ‘distasteful’ joke about U.S. women’s hockey team
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Team USA captain Hilary Knight criticized Donald Trump's joke about the U.S. women's hockey team as 'distasteful'.
The U.S. women's hockey team declined Trump's invitation to the State of the Union due to prior commitments.
U.S. men's hockey team apologized for laughing at Trump's remark, emphasizing their respect for the women’s team's achievements.
